member.name: T:OpenTap.Cli.CommandLineArgumentAttribute
member.summary: When used on a property inside a , this attribute indicates a command line arugment or switch.
member.remarks: The property type can be: bool, string, or string[]. If it's bool the argument will not take an argument, but will instead set the property to true. If it's a string the value of the property will be set to the first occuring value set in the CLI arguments. If it's a string[] all values set in the CLI arguments will be concatenated into an array.

member.name: T:OpenTap.DisplayAttribute
member.summary: Defines how a property, class, enum, or other item is presented to the user. Also configures the description and allows items to be grouped and ordered.

member.name: P:OpenTap.DisplayAttribute.Description
member.summary: Optional text that provides a description of the item. Consider using HelpLinkAttribute if a link to documentation is needed.

member.name: P:OpenTap.DisplayAttribute.Group
member.summary: Optional text used to group displayed items. Use 'Groups' if more than one level of grouping is needed.

member.name: P:OpenTap.DisplayAttribute.Name
member.summary: Name displayed by the UI.

member.name: P:OpenTap.DisplayAttribute.Order
member.summary: Optional integer that ranks items and groups in ascending order relative to other items/groups. Default is -10000. For a group, the order is the average order of the elements inside the group. Any double value is allowed. Items with same order are ranked alphabetically.
member.remarks: This applies only to properties. Classes will ignore this setting and be ordered alphabetically.

member.name: P:OpenTap.DisplayAttribute.Collapsed
member.summary: Boolean setting that indicates whether a group's default appearance is collapsed. Default is 'false' (group is expanded).

member.name: M:OpenTap.DisplayAttribute.GetFullName
member.summary: Gets the Group (or Groups) and Name concatenated with a backslash (\).

member.name: F:OpenTap.DisplayAttribute.DefaultOrder
member.summary: The default order for display attribute. This is set in this way to highlight the fact that an order is not set and out of the range of normally selected order values. '0' for example is a commonly selected value for order, so it could not be that.

member.name: M:OpenTap.DisplayAttribute.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Double,System.Boolean,System.String[])
member.summary: Creates a new instance of . Ensures that Name is never null.
member.param: Name displayed by the UI.
Optional text that provides a description of the item. Consider using HelpLinkAttribute if a link to documentation is needed.
Optional text used to group displayed items. Use 'Groups' if more than one level of grouping is needed.

Optional integer that ranks items and groups in ascending order relative to other items/groups. Default is defined by DisplayAttribute.DefaultOrder. For a group, the order is the average order of the elements inside the group. Any double value is allowed. Items with same order are ranked alphabetically.
Boolean setting that indicates whether a group's default appearance is collapsed. Default is 'false' (group is expanded).
Optional array of text strings to specify multiple levels of grouping. Use 'Group' if only one level of grouping is needed.

member.name: M:OpenTap.DisplayAttribute.Equals(System.Object)
member.summary: Overriding Equals to fix strange equality issues between instances of DisplayAttribute.

member.name: T:OpenTap.ParameterMemberData
member.summary: A member that represents a parameter. The parameter controls the value of a set of parameterized members. Parameterized members can be added/removed using IMemberData.Parameterize() and IMemberData.Unparameterize()
member.remarks: The first member have special meaning since it decides which attributes the parameter will have. If the member is later removed from the parameter (unparameterized), the first additional member will take its place.

member.name: P:OpenTap.ParameterMemberData.Attributes
member.summary: Gets the attributes on this member.

member.name: P:OpenTap.ParameterMemberData.Target
member.summary: The target object to which this member is added. This should always be the same as the argument to GetValue/SetValue.

member.summary: Gets the value of this member.

member.name: M:OpenTap.ParameterMemberData.SetValue(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Sets the value of this member on the owner.

member.summary: The members and objects that make up the aggregation of this parameter.

member.name: P:OpenTap.ParameterMemberData.DeclaringType
member.summary: The target object type.

member.name: P:OpenTap.ParameterMemberData.TypeDescriptor
member.summary: The declared type of this property. This is the type of the first member added to the parameter. Subsequent members does not need to have the same type, but they should be conversion compatible. e.g if the first member is an int, subsequent members can be other numeric types or string as well.

member.name: P:OpenTap.ParameterMemberData.Writable
member.summary: If this member is writable. Usually true for parameters.

member.name: P:OpenTap.ParameterMemberData.Readable
member.summary: If this member is readable. Usually true for parameters.

member.name: P:OpenTap.ParameterMemberData.Name
member.summary: The declared name of this parameter. This parameter can be referred to by this name. It may contain spaces etc.

member.name: M:OpenTap.ParameterMemberData.RemoveMember(OpenTap.IMemberData,System.Object)
member.summary: Removes a forwarded member. If it was the original member, the first additional member will be used. If no additional members are present, then true will be returned, signalling that the forwarded member no longer exists.
member.param: The forwarded member.
The object owning 'delMember'
member.returns: True if the last member/source pair has been removed. If this happens the parameter should be removed from the target object.

member.name: T:OpenTap.EmbedPropertiesAttribute
member.summary: This attribute is used to dynamically embed the properties of an object into another object.
member.remarks: A property of type PT declared on a type DT decorated with this attribute will not be visible in reflection information (ITypeData) for DT. Instead all properties declared on PT will be visible on DT as though they had been declared there.

member.name: P:OpenTap.EmbedPropertiesAttribute.PrefixPropertyName
member.summary: When true, property name of the owning property is used as prefix for embedded properties. E.g., the name will be 'EmbeddedProperty.X'. A prefix can help prevent name-clashing issues if multiple properties gets the same name.

member.name: P:OpenTap.EmbedPropertiesAttribute.Prefix
member.summary: Custom prefix for embedded properties. This will overwrite PrefixPropertyName. A prefix can help prevent name-clashing issues if multiple properties gets the same name.

member.name: M:OpenTap.EmbeddedMemberData.loadAndTransformAttributes
member.summary: Loads and transform the list of attributes. Some attributes are sensitive to naming, the known ones are AvailableValuesAttribute, SuggestedValueAttribute, and EnabledIf. Others might exist, but they are, for now, not supported. When NoPrefix is set on EmbedProperties, then there is no issue, but with the prefix, those names also needs to be transformed. Additionally, there is some special behavior wanted for Display, for usability and to avoid name clashing: - If a Display name/group is set on the owner property, that should turn into a group for the embedded properties. - If there is no display name, use the prefix name for the group. - If there is no prefix name, don't touch DisplayAttribute.

member.name: T:OpenTap.ITestPlanImport

member.remarks: The developer determines the content and complexity of classes that implement this type. It might be as simple as unzipping a TestPlan, or as complex as reading a well-defined Excel file that represents some TestPlan data.

member.name: P:OpenTap.ITestPlanImport.Extension
member.summary: The extension of the imported file including the '.'. For example '.zip'.

member.summary: Imports a file. The contents of the file can be an entire TestPlan, or data to be inserted into a dynamically created TestPlan.
member.param: The absolute or relative path to file.
member.returns: The test plan constructed as part of the Import.

member.summary: The extension of the exported file including the '.'. For example '.zip'.

member.name: P:OpenTap.ITestPlanExport.Name

member.name: M:OpenTap.ITestStep.PrePlanRun
member.summary: Called by TestPlan.Run() for each step in the test plan prior to calling the TestStepBase.Run() methods of each step.

member.name: M:OpenTap.ITestStep.Run
member.summary: Called by TestPlan.Run() to run each TestStep. If this step has children (ChildTestSteps.Count > 0), then these are executed instead.

member.name: M:OpenTap.ITestStep.PostPlanRun
member.summary: Called by TestPlan.Run() after completing all TestStepBase.Run() methods in the TestPlan Note that TestStep.PostPlan run is run in reverse order For example, if you had three Tests (T1, T2, and T3), and T2 was disabled, then PrePlanRun would run for T1 and T3 (in that order) PostPlanRun would run for T3 and T1 (in that order)

member.name: M:OpenTap.ResultSource.PublishResultTableInvokable.CreateOptimizedTable(OpenTap.WorkQueue)
member.summary:
If possible, introspect the current work queue and collapse result table propagations into one. This can give a huge performance boost for many use cases, but mostly when PublishTable is not used.
Note that this has to be done in the result listener thread - since each may have different number of elements queued depending on the speed of the result listener. Slow ones like internet based ones will have more items queued.
member.returns: An optimized table or the original one if it is not possible to optimize.

member.summary: Parses one or more items of 'property', replacing '%' with the value of the property given after formatting. Note that 'property' must be a property with the , and 'src' is the object containing 'property', not the value of the property. If property.PropertyType is bool, then from the value 'A|B' A is selected if true, and B is selected if false.

member.name: T:OpenTap.SemanticVersion
member.summary: Version object for OpenTAP versions. Adheres to Semantic Version 2.0 formatting and behavior, see http://semver.org. Supported formats: Major.Minor.Patch Major.Minor.Patch-PreRelease Major.Minor.Patch+BuildMetadata. Major.Minor.Patch-PreRelease+BuildMetadata.

member.name: F:OpenTap.SemanticVersion.Major
member.summary: Major version. Incrementing this number signifies a backward incompatible change in the API.

member.name: F:OpenTap.SemanticVersion.Minor
member.summary: Minor version. Incrementing this number usually signifies a backward compatible addition to the API.

member.name: F:OpenTap.SemanticVersion.Patch
member.summary: Patch version. Incrementing this number signifies a change that is both backward and forward compatible.

member.name: F:OpenTap.SemanticVersion.BuildMetadata
member.summary: Optional build related metadata. Usually a short git commit hash (8 chars). Ignored when determining version presedence. Only ASCII alphanumeric characters and hyphen is allowed [0-9A-Za-z-]

member.name: F:OpenTap.SemanticVersion.PreRelease
member.summary: Optional pre-release version, denoted by a -. Only ASCII alphanumeric characters and hyphen is allowed [0-9A-Za-z-]. A pre-release version indicates that the version is unstable and might not satisfy the intended compatibility requirements as denoted by its associated normal version.

member.name: M:OpenTap.SemanticVersion.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new SemanticVersion instance
member.param: Major version. Incrementing this number signifies a backward incompatible change in the API.
Minor version. Incrementing this number usually signifies a backward compatible addition to the API.
Patch version. Incrementing this number signifies a change that is both backward and forward compatible.
Optional pre-release version, denoted by a -. Only ASCII alphanumeric characters and hyphen is allowed [0-9A-Za-z-].
Optional build related metadata. Usually a short git commit hash (8 chars). Ignored when determining version presedence. Only ASCII alphanumeric characters and hyphen is allowed [0-9A-Za-z-]

member.name: M:OpenTap.SemanticVersion.TryParse(System.String,OpenTap.SemanticVersion@)
member.summary: Tries to parse a SemanticVersion from string. Input must strictly adhere to http://semver.org for this method to return true.
member.returns: True if the string was sucessfully parsed.

member.name: M:OpenTap.SemanticVersion.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: Parses a SemanticVersion from string. In addition to the http://semver.org format, this also supports a four value number (x.x.x.x) which will be interpreted as Major.Minor.BuildMetadata.Patch. The non semver format is supported to be compatible with Microsofts definition of version numbers (e.g. for .NET assemblies), see https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.version

member.name: T:OpenTap.SessionLogs
member.summary: SessionLogs are logs of all events that occur during startup/shutdown of a OpenTAP session and of all the session's TestPlan runs. A new session log is created at the start of each session, which starts when a process is launched and ends when it closes. Only 10 session logs are allowed to exist, with the oldest deleted as new logs are created. By comparison, a result log typically shows only the log activity for a single run of a TestPlan.

member.name: F:OpenTap.SessionLogs.maxNumberOfTraceFiles
member.summary: The number of files kept at a time.

member.name: F:OpenTap.SessionLogs.maxNumberOfConcurrentSessions
member.summary: If two sessions needs the same log file name, an integer is added to the name. This is the max number of times that we are going to test new names.

member.summary: Called by TestPlan.Run() for each step in the test plan prior to calling the method of each step.

member.name: M:OpenTap.TestStep.PostPlanRun
member.summary: Called by TestPlan.Run() after completing all methods in the . ///
member.remarks: Note that run is run in reverse order. For example, suppose you had three tests: T1, T2, and T3. PrePlanRun would run for T1, T2 and T3 (in that order), and PostPlanRun would run for T3, T2 and T1 (in that order).

member.name: T:OpenTap.NumberUnitSplitter
member.summary: A number unit splitter can split a text into numbers and units using whitespaces and changes from digits to characters as splitting points.

member.name: M:OpenTap.NumberUnitSplitter.Split(System.String,System.Globalization.NumberStyles,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Splits a string into pairs of numbers and units. The units are not evaluated in any way but just returned as strings. Separation points are whitespaces, any switch from digits to characters and vice versa. Dots, commas etc. are considered to belong to numbers, also the character 'e' when it is followed by a sign or digit. You can provide parsing parameters though that may render such a number invalid. For empty input strings, an empty list is returned. In case of invalid numbers, an FormatException is thrown.
member.param: The text.
The accepted styles for number parsing.
The culture for number parsing. If omitted, DefaultThreadCurrentCulture is chosen.
member.returns: A List<Tuple<double,string>>

member.name: M:OpenTap.NumberUnitSplitter.GetLeadingDigits(System.String,System.Globalization.NumberStyles,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Retrieves the leading part of the string that contains digits only and an optional set of formatting signs. Note that the returned string may even consist of formatting signs only like ",.-+e+" so you should use the .NET type parser on the result determine if it is an actual number.
member.param: The string to parse.
This can be configured to accept the features decimal delimiter, leading sign and exponent.
true to include leading white space characters.
member.returns: The leading digits.

member.name: T:OpenTap.TimeSpanFormatter
member.summary: Contains helper functions to format a time span into a human readable string.

member.name: M:OpenTap.TimeSpanFormatter.Format(System.TimeSpan,OpenTap.FormatVerbosities,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Formats a timespan to a string like "3 min 4 sec".
member.param: The timespan.
The verbosity.
true to insert a space before each unit.
true to include those parts of the timespan that are zero, starting with hours, e.g. "0h 2m 0s" instead of just "2m".
true to include, false to exclude the fractions of the second portion.
The Culture to use for number formatting. Since milliseconds are displayed as fractions of seconds, this effects the decimal delimiter. By default, the DefaultThreadCurrentCulture is used.
member.returns: The formatted value.

member.name: T:OpenTap.TimeSpanParser
member.summary: A time span parser can parse a text input (which would typically be a user input) for timespan information like "1 hour 2 minutes" or "1 week 250ms" and sum them all up into a TimeSpan. Currently only English units are supported.

member.name: M:OpenTap.TimeSpanParser.Parse(System.String,System.Globalization.NumberStyles,System.Globalization.CultureInfo,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Parses a string for TimeSpan Information like "1 week 2 days" or "2h12m3s". Currently only English units are accepted. Note that "month" is not a valid unit, since it does not correspond to a determined number of days and so is "year" because of leap years. However you can have both units parsed to hardwired values using the parameter. Note that Microseconds are accepted, but the .NET TimeSpan only resolves milliseconds. Thus only multiples of thousands of Microseconds will affect the result, e.g. "2000s", when reformatted, will evaluate to "2ms" whereas "200s" will simply return TimeSpan.Zero.
member.exception: Thrown when one or more arguments have unsupported or illegal values.
Thrown when a unit is unknown.
member.param: The input string.
The acceptable number styles.
The culture for number parsing. If omitted, DefaultThreadCurrentCulture is chosen.
true to accept months (as 30 days) and years (as 356 days).
member.returns: A TimeSpan.

member.name: T:OpenTap.WorkQueue
member.summary: Work Queue used for result processing in sequence but asynchronously. It uses the ThreadManager to automatically clean up threads that have been idle for a while. When the WorkQueue is disposed, the used thread is immediately returned to the ThreadManager.

member.summary: Options for WorkQueues.

member.name: F:OpenTap.WorkQueue.Options.None
member.summary: No options.

member.name: F:OpenTap.WorkQueue.Options.LongRunning
member.summary: The thread is not returned to the ThreadManager when it has been idle for some time. In this situation the WorkQueue must be disposed manually.

member.name: F:OpenTap.WorkQueue.Options.TimeAveraging
member.summary: Time averaging is enabled. Each piece of work will have measured time spent.

member.name: F:OpenTap.WorkQueue.Timeout
member.summary: The amount of idle time to wait before giving the thread back to the threading manager. This has no effect if the LongRunning option is selected.

member.name: P:OpenTap.WorkQueue.AverageTimeSpent
member.summary: The average time spent for each task. Only available if Options.TImeAveraging is enabled.

member.name: P:OpenTap.WorkQueue.QueueSize
